text: hello and welcome to community chats i'm
your host ali hammer and today we're
joined with lucy wang a solution
architect who is part of our aws grad
program
techyu so lucy welcome to the show i
mean you've been with aws for just over
a year now
first as an intern and then converting
to a grad position
so can you start by telling our audience
a little bit about the grad program
techyu sure thanks so much for having me
here today ali
so the aws tegu program you know
according to the job description
is an accelerated program for those who
want to advance both their technical and
business skills
it's a really good way for students to
start their career
as a solutions architect a professional
services consultant or a few other
technical roles
but it's a lot more than that because
over the course of six months we get the
opportunity to learn
about the different services aws offers
and then we use the knowledge to build
proof of concepts and presentations
based on mock customer scenarios
so during this training period we're
also encouraged to shadow people working
in different areas across aws
and towards the end we work on a
capstone project in teams to bring
together all the knowledge we've
gathered over the past
six months so i've been in this program
for around three months now
and i've honestly learnt so much about
how to talk to customers and how to
communicate technical concepts to people
with different levels of cloud knowledge
it's so great that you get to work
across so many different parts of the
business
and that you're also given the
opportunity to shadow some of our
smartest people
and lose as i mentioned before you
actually started off at aws as an intern
so what was the experience like and what
was your favorite part about interning
at amazon over the summer
yeah it was actually really good so when
i joined as an intern last year
um everyone was working from home so
there were definitely a few challenges
at the beginning with
you know figuring out how to make the
most out of a virtual experience
but overall i really enjoyed my time as
an intern because i had a very
supportive team
who placed a lot of trust in me and
through that i was able to take
ownership of three projects
and was given both the guidance and
autonomy to decide how i wanted to
deliver results
and i would say my favorite part of the
internship especially towards the second
half of it when we had more
opportunities to go into the office
was just being able to make new friends
and meet people in other teams
there's so many different teams at aws
so it's always really interesting to
hear about what others are working on
i mean i can imagine that it would have
been just so exciting to
you know have this opportunity to intern
at aws with like-minded people
especially during such a difficult time
i mean i know it was quite difficult to
land yourself you know an internship
during cobin so
i'm so glad that you got that experience
aside from the challenges from working
from home though
were there any other challenges that you
did face as an intern or even now that
you might face as a grad
yeah definitely so when you go into a
new role as an internal grad
there can be a lot of uncertainty around
what exactly you're supposed to do and
how everything fits in together
and i would say my biggest challenge was
learning how to navigate around all this
uncertainty
i found that the best way to deal with
all of this was to not be afraid to ask
questions
and because there's a lot of information
available on internal websites
it can be hard knowing where to start so
another thing i found really
helpful was building relationships with
those around me
because we could collaborate more and
share our knowledge and i would say it's
also really important to embrace
uncertainty as an intern
or grad because not knowing much about
how everything fits in together at a
company means that you can sort of bring
in a fresh perspective to the team
i mean i love what you're saying about
you know that you learn to embrace
uncertainty it's something that i'm
still learning and working on every day
and it's a skill that definitely is
going to help you out in your working
career
so finally lucy what advice do you have
for students who might be watching this
who are interested in
applying you know for either an
internship or a grad job and
i guess any tips to make them help them
stand out in that job application
process
yeah that's a great question ali i would
say that most of the preparation
students can do is actually before they
press the apply now button
so keep an eye out for opportunities to
speak with aws representatives through
virtual in-person events
whether that be a careers fair technical
workshop or panel discussion
you can also get started with your cloud
learning journey by preparing for an aws
certification
and there's so many resources and
programs offered by aws to support
students along the way
and when it comes to applying for an
internship or graduate program
instead of sending out a generic resume
for every role
always remember to tailor your resume
based on what you see on the job
description
but overall just be yourself be well
prepared and
remember to always be enthusiastic
throughout the whole process
thank you so much luce i mean those are
really good tips also remember to
mention the
aws leadership principles because that's
what we live and breathe here
um but i've so enjoyed having you on the
show we're gonna get you back in a few
weeks time to talk
about certifications and some other
topics so
thank you so much luce and if anyone has
